div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

Editor and Manager - - R. SNELLING.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1907.

div.head: FINANCIAL PROSPECTS IN LONDON.
div.p: Egypt depends so very much on London, as far as the money market is concerned, that any impartial view of the situation there, is of great interest to us. The following extract from "The Times" of the 28th October appears to be a peculiarly faithful picture of prospects in London and as such deserves reproduction :

"Apart from the American troubles, the persistently low level of the Paris cheque is a rather disturbing feature, and well-informed advices from Paris point to the probability of its permanence for the present, perhaps until the end of the quarter. On the other hand, the lateness of the cotton crop and a slackening in the demand for cotton in Lancashire are tending to postpone the withdrawal of sovereigns to Egypt and also account for the slowness with which cotton bills come forward from the United States. Trade also shows some sign of slackening in the provinces, and some bankers report a legs eager demand for credit At their branches in the industrial centres. There is thus good reason to hope that if the demands and discomforts of the current quarter can be surmounted without serious strain, & period of more normal monetary conditions may be expected confidently. In fact, there is some justification for the view that after a long period of difficulty and readjustment a spell of decided ease may make its appearance The shock to credit, and the crop of further disclosures which may be reckoned on with only too much certainty, in the United States, will almost certainly tend to a severe restriction of financial operations on the other side of the Atlantic. Much of the strain of thọ past two years has been due to the fact that New York was enabled, by the assistance given to it too readily by London, to command London's resources without applying London's skill and caution in the handling of them. Those who were responsible for the too ready granting of this assistance have been gently but firmly repressed, and London has resumed control of its own resources. This change in the position has been to a great extent responsible for the liquidation in New York, which suddenly found its banker turning a deaf bar to the voice of its charming We can thue infer that the present inconveniences, though disagreeable enough, arise from a genuine and deep-seated improvement in the situation. There is still a long valley full of mist and bogs and mantraps to be groped through, but it is possible to discern a ray of sunlight sleeping on the far distant hilltops."

div.head: The Railway Budget
div.p: It is rumoured that the Railway Administration's budget has been subjected to considerable reductions this year.

div.head: Gum Arabic.
div.p: Last week gum arabic of the dark quality was sold in the local markets at P.T. 118 the cantar (approximately 90 lbs.)

div.head: The Vernacular Press.
div.p: A new daily paper is shortly to be published by Hussein Effendi Barto under the title of "Al Maglis Al Naibi."

div.head: The Ghezireh Project.
div.p: We understand that the project of building Government flats at Ghezireh for which plans were recently prepared has been abandoned.

div.head: The Hedjaz Railway.
div.p: Mustapha Bey Khalifa has handed over a sum of L.T. 100 to Ghazi Mokhtar Pasha in payment of his annual subscription towards the construction of the Hedjaz railway.

div.head: Islamic Benevolent Society.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Khalil Pasha Hamadi, anid Ahmed Pasha Yehia have each con. tributed P.T. 50 to the Islamic Benevolent Society.

div.head: Ministry of Education.
div.p: Abdel Rahman Effendi Kassab and Mohamed Ali Effendi Lutfi have been selected to replace the two students who refused to remain at Broadwood College, Nottingham.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandria, at 3.15 p.m. on Sunday 3rd for ordinary correspondence, 2.15 p.m. for register. ed correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p.in. on Saturday 2nd for parcels.

div.head: Islamic Congress.
div.p: The editor of "Al Moayad" has issued invitations for an Islamic Congress, which is to hold its first meeting this evening at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo. Ismail Bey Gos. prensky, Editor of the "Terdjuman," is the promoter of the movement, and he will give a discourse in Turkish.

div.head: German Paper for Egypt.
div.p: Next month a weekly German newspaper will commence publication at Cairo. Its object will be to protect German interests in Egypt. Hitherto German journals in this country have not been a success, the "Levant Zeitung" and the "Aegyptische Karrier" only having lived for a very short time.

div.head: An Illusionist.
div.p: Mr. de Lafontaine, an illusionist of fame, has arrived in Alexandria and will commence to morrow a series of seances. Mr. de Lafontaine has gained considerable fame as thought reader and hypnotist and gained a great success at the Paris exhibition of 1900. Among his subjects is the noted medium Mlle Myralda, 1 subject of Dr. Charest.

div.head: Tramcar Accident
div.p: Yesterday morning tramcar No 135 collided with the Cairo Garrison School omnibus near the abbatoir. The omnibus was upset, and, besides considerable injury resulting to one of the mules, two children of Mr. W H. Bailey were hurt and all the occupants received a severe shock. The police have taken the matter in hand and we understand that an action for damages will be taken against the Tramway Co.

div.head: Jewish School Question.
div.p: The most important topic debated at a recent meeting of the Anglo-Jewish Association was the question whether the association should continue the grants that it has been in the habit of making to the "Alliance" schools in Cairo and Alexandria for the provision of English teachers. The opinion was expressed that the Jewish communities in Egypt should themselves provide the money for English instruction. But as Mr. Montefiore pointed out, if this attitude should be adopted there is great danger that the Egyptian Jews would be lost to Judaism. Jewish parents in Egypt require good English teaching for their children and unless they can obtain this in the "Alliance schools they will, in all probability, withdraw their patronage from the Jewish schools altogether.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: La 10me Exposition de chrysanthèmes aura lieu sous les auspices de S. A. le Khédive, samedi et dimanche après-midi, à partir de 3 heures 1/2. A cette occasion, il y aura concert les deux jours de suite. Dimanche à 6 heures précises grand spectacle cinématographique comme d'habitude donné par la maison "Urbanora."
L'entrée à l'exposition sera gratuite pour les abonnés du Casino.

div.head: THE AMERICAN CRISIS.
div.p: RUMOURED FRENCH LOAN.
ORDERS FROM PHILADELPHIA.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday.
The report that the Banque de France is lending three millions is untrue, though it is possible that they may buy bills for which they will pay gold, and thus relieve the situation.
Philadelphia has ordered coin immediately to the extent of fifteen million dollars in gold double eagles.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive attended Friday prayers today at the Mosque of Sidi Abdul Rahman Ibn el Hormos in Ras-el-Tin street..
Tomorrow night, being the Leilet el Kadr, his Highness will pray at the Mosque of Sidi el Abbns near the Custom House.

div.head: A HELOUAN PROBLEM.
div.p: Cairo has a very efficient fire brigade, but has it ever struck the residents of Helouan that in case of fire any dwelling there would be almost certainly doomed to entire destruction ? Has this little matter escaped the notice of the authorities also, or is it considered of two little consequence to receive the immediate attention that it would almost appear to demand?

We cannot blame the fire brigade, for we find that they have a manual there and have made all arrangements possible to cope with A fire should one occur, but however good their intentions, we fear that their efforts would be of but little avail, for the simple reason that hydrants are lacking in number: less places where they should be found and that the pressure of such water as is available is too feeble to be of any material assistance.

In case of a large fire at one of the great hotels for instance what arrangements are made for taking men and appliances out to Helouan in time for their services to be of any avail? Is there a special truck standing in readiness at the Bab el Louk station, or are we living in the hope that the much talked of road may be finished before there is any need for the sudden transportation of men and machines to our salubrious suburb?

We trust that the authorities will take immediate steps to remedy the present state of affairs. It is little short of disgraceful that a town of the importance of Helouan should be practically left to the mercy of any fire which should chance to break out. If a big fire did ocenr no effort would be considered too great in order to guard against a second disaster. Why not start now and guard against a first?

div.head: EGYPTIAN FOSSILS.
div.p: New York, Oct. 7.- The American Museum of Natural History has just received from Egypt twenty-seven cases of rare fossils, about six hundred specimens in all, comprising forms new to science, exceedingly valuable fossils of the ancestral elephant and of an extraordinary beast, the arsinoitherium, which is not closely related to any living form or any extinct group. It is conservatively estimated by geologists that these animals existed more than a million years ago.
These fossils are the product of an expedition financed by Morris K. Jerop, president of the museum, and sent to Northern Egypt under the direction of Prof. Henry P. Osborne.

div.head: THE HARDEN ACCUSATIONS.
div.p: PRINCE EULENBERG'S CASE.
PROBABILITY OF PROSECUTION.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday.

The Harden scandals continue to absorb the interest of Europe and columns of the Press are devoted to the revelations and their results. A report comes from Berlin that legal action will be taken against Prince Eulenberg.

div.head: SUDAN FINANCES.
div.p: It is a comparatively short time since the Sudan was reclaimed to civilization, and it is therefore extremely gratifying to learn that Egypt's contribution to her finances is to be reduced by L.E. 45,000 this year.

The making of a country is at all times an expensive proceeding, and it would not have been surprising if the Sudan had been forced to call upon Egypt for continued financial support for a much longer period than is apparently necessary, and even had this been the case the value of the Sadan as commanding the water supply of Egypt would have been sufficient justification of the expenditure.

With each successive expedition to the Upper Nile for the purpose of "sudd" cutting the water supply of Egypt was rendered more secure, while the early information regarding the probable height of the Nile, which until recent years it was impossible to obtain, is of inestimable value to the dwellers in Lower Egypt.

Egypt has therefore every reason to be satisfied with the way in which the Sudan has dealt with her financial resources and we trust that this additional drain upon her budget for the coming year will not prove to be premature.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPH ENTERTAINMENT.
div.p: Port Said, Thursday, On Tuesday night the Eldorado theatre was crowded with residents and passengers. A special programme had been arranged by Mr. Maurice B. Bandmann (of the Bandmann Opera Co.) who was passing through Port Said en route to Calcutta with the bioscope films from the Alhambra, London. The most interesting items on the programme were the fights between Gonner Moir and Jack Palmer for the middle wight boxing championship, and the match between Gunner Moir and Tiger Smith for the championship of England. Both fight were clearly shown and very interesting. The race for the Grand National, a football match at the Crystal Palace and many other subjects were also well worth seeing.

div.head: Arrivals.
div.p: Among the passengers to disembark here this morning from the 8.8. "Ortona" were Capt. Adams, Miss Eaton, Miss Matthew, the Misses Wells, Mrs. Matthew, Miss M. E. Ban, Mrs. Coles, the Misses Coles, Miss Alston, Mrs. W. A. Hart, Mrs. Nerton Kysche, Mrs. Yeo, Mr. L E. Ellis, Miss McCallum, Mr. G. BAVAS tro, and Mrs. Deatherman.
Mr., Mrs., and Mr. C. Broatoh arrived here this morning from England by the S.S. "Martaban."

div.head: Cricket Season Reviewed.
div.p: The Port Said I.S. Club have probably finished cricket for this season and a glance at the results may be of interest. The Club have played 19 matches with mail boats and H. M's. ships. Nine have been won, eight lost, and two drawn, which is satisfactory, considering the number of players who have been on holiday this year. The, batting averages of the first six player are as follows. A. J. Tweedie tops the list with an average of 28.3. total runs scored 256 in 9 completed innings. B.J. Williams comes second with 13.8, total runs 120 in 9 innings ; third Dr. Ouffey with 10.7, total runs 75 in 7 innings ; fourth A. H. King with 8.8, total runs 106 in 12 innings; fifth A. V. Wallis with 8.7, total runs 96 in 11 innings; sixth R. Tweedie with 7.1, total runs 64 in 9 innings. Mr. A. V. Wallia is to be congratulated on the way he captained the club, and it is due to his personal vigorous enthusiasm that the club has had such a good season's sport. A word of praise must also be given to Mr. John Chesman, who has carried out his duties as hon. sec. to perfection.

div.head: BANKING IN EGYPT.
div.p: AMERICAN BANK WANTED.

United States Consul-General Iddings bas transmitted a report prepared by a clerk in the Cairo consulate to Washington on the excellent opportunity for the establishment of an American bank in Egypt. He recommends that a central institution be established in Cairo with branches in the other leading cities. A list of Egyptian banks forwarded is on file in the bureau of manufactures.

div.head: NEW BANK FOR CAIRO.
div.p: We understand that Messrs Gusman and Deptamaro, the well-know contractors of Sharia el Boulac intend extending their business shortly by opening a bank in Cairo which is to deal with mortgages, stocks and shares, etc.

div.head: ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: Evidently the earning capacity of the AngloEgyptian Bank has not been affected by the events during the last twelve months in the land of the Delta. Dealing with the profits of that period, the directors propose a final dividend of 108. per share, making a total distri. botion of 15 per cent, for the year, whilat £40,000 is added to reserve, £10,000 to pen. sion fund, and £85,000 is carried forward, This compares with the same distribution a year ago when £60,000 was added to reserve, £!0,000 to pension fund, and £29,000 carried forward. Practically, therefore, the result is the same as that announced last year, in face of the important crisis that has been traversed in the time, and the result harmonises with the view we have taken all through, that the English-managed banka in Egypt had handled the difficult position presented by the unwieldy speculation some time back on the Egyptian Bourses in an admirable manner. Thanks to their foresight and decision, the difficulty was confined within narrow channels, and with the bumper crop now being handled the unfavorable influences ought to pass out of sight.
"Evening Standard."

div.head: CORN MILL FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A correspondent writes to the "Westminster Gazette :"

One of the factors contributing to the recent rapid advance in the cost of wheat in this country and the consequent increase in the price of bread has been the augmented supplies taken in recent years by China, Japan, and Egypt. The Eastern Empires are diverting a large part of the American crop which formerly found its way to this land. To Egypt large and continuously growing shipments of floor are made from this country.

Preliminary engagements have now been completed which will have an important effect on the British milling trade. Wheat has in the past been brought from Russia, milled in this country, and exported to Egypt. It has now been determined to erect A great milling-plant in the neighbourhood of Alexandria, at which consignments of wheat from Russia will be dealt with as well as such supplies as are grown in Egypt. Egyptian wheat does not of itself contain the finest constituents of work. able flour, but mixed with that from other lands is a valuable commodity. At present, in Egypt, there is no modern milling-plaut. There are many of the primitive stone-mills which have come down from time immemorial.

This new enterprise, to which reference is inade, will be on the most modern scale. The plant to be laid down will cost about half a million. Work, it is anticipated, will commence early in 1908, and before the close of the year it is expected to have the mill running.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA HOUSE
div.p: In a recent issue we published a rumour to the effect that the question of an Opera house had been settled, and expressed surprise that the Government should have plunged into the enormous expenditure of LE. 300,000 on a house to meet the requirements of a three months' season. We are now authorized to state that the question has been entirely shelved for the present, and that no price has been decided upon. While regretting that it has not been considered possible to settle the question at the present time, we are glad to learn that the Government has not rushed into the expense rumoured, especially as it would appear that the matter had not been offered for tender.

div.head: OSTRICH FEATHER SALES.
div.p: The quarterly sales concluded in London on the 10th ult. comprised 356 cases Egyptian, of which about 310 cases Egyptian sold The quantity catalogued was very large, and much of it was rather poor quality, prices for this description were generally 10 to 15 per cent cheaper; good quality, which was only in moderate supply, sold well, although in some instances this also sold slightly in buyers' favor.
A good assortment of Egyptian feathers mostly sold with good competition, the changes being similar as in Cape goods.
The quantity of Cape and Egyptian feathers sold realised 222,000.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: On arrival at Cairo the Dutch and Duchess of Devonshire and Lord and Lily Coaford went to Shepherd's Hotel, where they are at present staying. Other visitors to be Hotel include Lady Theodore Agbon Charles Hartoph. and Dr. Plato The booking of rooms and apartments at this hotel are we learn, numerous and anger for an excellent reason.

Mr. Klobokowati, who has been on a special mission in Abyssinia, is expected shortly in Cairo. It is rumoured that he will shortly be called to fill an important position in the French Foreign Office.
Dr. J. B. Christopherson, Director of the Sadan Medical Department, is leaving Cairo this evening for Khartoum.
Messrs. Reid and Barnard have transferred their Cairo offices to No. 7 Sharis, Chawubi Pasha, opposite the Hotel Villa Victoria.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt this morning by Cook. Nila steamer "Hatasoo" :-Mr. and Mr. George Zananiri Bey, Captain and Mr. Leon Verbol, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Bredlay, Mr. and the Misses Wanklyn, Mrs. Arthur King, Miss Julia Ungubart, Mr. D. S. Cohen, Mr. and Mn. Milnor, Mr. and Mrs. Myers.

div.head: PIERRE LOTI IN EGYPT.
div.p: Pierre Loti's letter in the Figaro" of the 17th inst, is devoted to describing the catacombs of Apis, the bull god at Memphis. Though these have been written about by many a traveller from many a land, the sailor academician has contrived to find something now to say about the giant sarcophagi, and, needless to add, he says it in his peculiar and inimitable style. What strikes Loti most is the ancient sepulchre is not the empty granite shells, nor the stupendous labour of the worshippers of Apis. His text is really taken from a stone coffin that has never held mumm because, before it had been fitted into its niche the cult of Apis had ceased in the land.

It is the right of this "last" sarcophagus which inspires him with the terrifying thought --the most terrible, he says, of all our positive notions--that there must be an end to everything, not only a last temple, a last priest, and a last tomb, but also a last child born on earth, a last sunrise, and a last sunset. His reflections recall the description given by Mariette Bey of his own feelings when he first entered this inighty mausoleum, and saw on the sand the footprint of the last Egyptian who had gone out and closed the door behind him 3700 years before.

div.head: The Guards Drafts for Egypt
div.p: The transport "Sicilia," which leaves Southampton to-day with the reinforcement for the 3rd Coldstream Guards in Egypt, is also to take drafts from various departmental corpe at Aldershot for Malta, Singapore, Ceylon, HongKong, and Tientsin."

Members sailing are specially notified that they must watch for their own special starting flag irrespective of whatever other flags may be flying.
Time guts will be fired at 2.00, 2.15 and 2.30p.m.
The starting buoy has been moved to about one cable S.E. of its usual position to make way for the rowing races.

All sailing yachts are particularly requested to keep clear of the rowing boats, whose course is from the Black And White to the Yacht Club, and are algo asked to give the rowing boats a wide barth so as not to make too much "wash" for the same. This is especially the case round the noishing buoy adjoining the Club House where the course of the towing boats crosses the finishing lina of the sailing yachts. The rowing yachts are timed to tako, place is follow and will finish approximately 10minutes after these times.

div.head: COMPTOIR FINANCIER ET COMMERCIAL D'EGYPTE
div.p: ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

The annual general meeting of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte was held at the head office of the Company at Alexandria at 4.30p.m. yesterday. Among those present were the Chairman of the Board of Directors, Khalil Pacha Khayat, the managing Director, Mr. Alfred Campos, and Meeure Aghian, Harry P. Barbsj and William Resswall Ress. Mattas Golund, General to the Company, and Muller Fahsdth Calamain, the auditors. At the begining of the meering, Messrs, Rudoplh Blathes and J. Zahpt were appointed to examine the list of shareholders. It was found that 44.000/themes were represented at the meeting out of a total of 125,000. As, however, quorum is not necessary for an ordinary meeting the proceedings began forthwith. A shareholder then rose and delivered some touching words in memory of the late Mr. Joseph Campos. Mr. Alfred Campos then read the following reporta :-
The following is the report of the anditors of the Company :- . Messieurs,

En dehors des frais généraux et d'amortis sement de mobilier, il a été en ontre placé sur les bénéfices une somme de P.T. 388.980.1. pour créances totalement perdaco.
Après con dédactions les bénéfom nota de 8: cet Exercice se sont élevén P.T.2.748 H1.16 plus le reliquat de lexercice
ce qui porte à.., P.T.8.066.999,00
le solde disponible de Compte Profita & Por tes & répartir conformément à l'Art. 29 desi Statuta,
Alexandria le 24 Octobre 1907.
Mr. Campos next proceeded to read the following report of the Board of Directors :-
Messieurs,
Nous avons l'honneur de vous noumettre lo Bilan et le compte Portes et Profita de notre second exarvico social, olon le ai juillet 1907.

En vous rendant cotopte den réonltata do cen exercice, nous devriong Mensieer faire sortir tous les progne nalade d'une anado l'autre, montrer d'une part le dardloppement de pos placements et de l'autre l'acorotagonnent de nos rekaodroed.

Si tel est l'objectif de toute entreprise notivelle, si notre souci constant a été tal, durant tont le premier semestre du dentar il n'en est pas moins vrai que la premier symptomes de la crise égyptienne rendaient nécessaire un changement dans notre ligne de conduite.

Catto crine est présente a tous, Elle a profondément affecte, il fant la dire le mon affaires. Elle n'a pas cependant, malgré toute Ha gravité, touché le pays dans og fond plus vives, ni dans son organiatno foonomiquo, qui demeare parfaitement "win. Si le cote financier a été quelque peu ébranlé, il restait. toujours un champ d'affaires considerable que maintenait la richesse agricole do paya

L'année 1907 restera donc une année ex: ceptionnelle. Elle n'aura pas une valeur statistique normale. C'est pourquoi, ai Peramen comparatif du Bilan actnet avec celui du prés. cédent exercice, ne révèle pas une augmenta. tion relative d'activité, le fait n'est que le résultat des mesures prudentes prises de la première heure de la crise.
Dans cet ordre d'idées nous pouvons nous déclarer satisfaits des résultats acquis jusqu'icj. Un examen détaillé nous permettra d'ailleurs de les préciser. se

Au 31 Juillet 1906 nok avances en reports s'élevaient & LE 216.772,622 mülmes. Vous remarquerer que ce chapitre n'existe pas dans le Bilan 1907. Depuis les premier mois de l'exercice nous avions, en effet tanu a rédaire graduellement l'importance de ce chapitre :

Pone appriaier, toata la poutto do pode comparison, il ne fanbpa perdre de vos ques:notro capital, qui était un 81 Jaillot 1000 de $ 260,000, a ste doublé dans l'intervallesame compter non rénerves qui atteignent près de £100,000.00
min Il est évident qu'en prenies des circonstancon excoptionnelles que troverait lo paya, nos
efforts ont tenda à ne pas augmenter nos placements en raison de l'acoroissement considérable de nos ressources. C'est la un résultat dont il nous semble superflu de sonligher l'importance.
Par contre, et comme corollaire indispensable de notre ligne de conduite, nous avons cherché à réduire fortement nos engagements.
Au 31 Juillet 1906 les comptes courants cré diteurs et nos comptes d'acceptation s'élevaient à la somme de... LE. 387.887,675
Au 31 Juillet 1907 ils ne présentent plus que ... . 187.296,314

Enfin, nous avons eu constamment en vne de renforcer nos disponibilités et de les maintenir à un chiffre élevé, mêine au risque de les laisser improductivos. Celles-ci se répartissent comme suit au 31 Juillet 1907.

Comme vous le voyez, Messieurs, ces mesares exceptionnelles nous ont permis de donner à la sitnation de notre Société toute la solidité et la souplesse désirables durant la période que nous avons traversée. Le Bilan très détaillé que nous soumettons votre approbation, pourra, d'ailleurs, vous en convaincre. Nous tenons, cependant, pour le préciser davantage, à vous donner quelques explieations complé. mentaires en ce qui concerne l'ensemble de nos placements. Ces derniers s'élèvent à LE. 645.667, 9996 dont :
Garanties par hypothèque. LE 102.881, 414

Ce genre d'opérations ne constitue pas, à proprement parler, une branche de notre pro. gramme. Nous avons été amenés au cours de la crise à exiger quelques hypothèques en garantie de certains comptes que les titulaires n'étaient pas à même de rembourser immédin. tement. Celles-ci sont de courte durée, réalisables au cours de l'année prochaine, et n'ont, par conséquent, aucun caractère d'immobili. Sation.
Garanties par effets.... LE 19.957, 686
Dans le même ordre d'idées que ci-dessus nous avons amélioré quelques-unes de nos avarices par ce supplément de garantie. Ce chapitre est peu important.
Garanties par titres... ... LE. 344.542, 168
Ces comptes sont entièrement converts par des titres calculés aux cours du 31 Juillet, qui, comme vous ne l'ignorez pas, sont à peu de chose près, les plus bas cours pratiqués durant la crise
Non garanties... ... ... LE 178.286,7316

Ce chapitre représente la partie non garantie de nos comptes courants. Néanmoins plusieurs de ces comptes se rapportent à des titulaires que nous considérons de tout repos. D'autres constituent des créances d'un caractère moins sur, et pour lesquelles votre Conseil a jugé utile de faire un prélèvement de L.E. 75,000 sur les bénéfices de l'exercice, ce qui, avec les LE. 7.500 de l'exercice 1905-1906, forme un total de LE 82,500 figurant au crédit du compte "Fonds de prévoyance." Nous estimons cette réserve spéciale suffisante pour couvrir les risques en cours.
Nous ajoutons quelques mots au sujet de la rubrique "Portefeuille" peu important d'ail. leurs, et qui figure au Bilan pour la soinme de L.E.5.611, 282.

Ce chapitre représente principalement les titres laissés pour compte, par quelques contreparties défaillantes. Cea titres ont été évalués au cours du 31 Juillet, et la perte en résultant, entièrement amortie. Ce chapitre est donc tout-à-fait accidentel, votre Société ayant toujours eu pour principe de s'abstenir de tout portefeuille en titres.
Nos bénéfices bruts se sont élevés ........... LE. 121.112, 9116
Nousy ajoutons le reliquat actionnaires de l'exercice précédent ...... 3.230, 1487
Nous en dédnisons :
Frais généraux.... ... LE 15.155, 030
Amortissement mobilier...136, 109
Créances perdues 3.389, 301
Fonds de prévoyance pour risques en cours … 75.000,
Il reste une somine nette de 30.662, 9203
dont il y a lieu de préle.
ver d'abord : 10% i la réserve statutaire
sur L.E27.432, 4716 LE 2.743, 2171 6% sur le capital verse,
soit £400,000 (montant déjà payé aux actionnaires en Février der
nier) ... ... ... ... 23.400, 6% d'intérêts l'an a forfait
da sur la dernière émis. sion de 25.000 actions à partir de la date des différents versements, soit P.T. 11,7 par action, dont vous etes appelés A fixer la date du paieinent......
Solde à reporter à nouveau, 1.594, 6732

Vous n'ignorez pas, Messieurs, que durant la période difficile qu'ont traversée les marchés égyptiens, plas dane affaire considérée de tout repos a perdu son carsotère normal, soit par la brusque dépréciation du gage, soit aussi par la valeur des signatures qui sabissaient an classement pouveau. la plus élémentaire prudence nous faisait ainsi on devoir de procéder à on exameo rigoureux de notre actif et à une appréciation très sévère des risques en cours. C'est

ce qui vous expliqne le chiffre important de LE 75 000, porta au chapitre "Ponda de prévoyance." Nous aimons à croire que vous approuverez sans hésitation cette mesure, ains que l'ensemble des comptes tels qu'ils vou sont présentée par votre Conseil.

Le nouvel exercice est ainsi garanti, croyons nous, contre tout mécompte pouvant résulte d'appréciations optimistes et ne pourra que bénéficier de toute amélioration ultérieure dan l'état général da marché. Déjà il s'est prodni depuis le 31 juillet un revirement assez ac centaé. Ce revirement, qne quelques-uns con sidèrent comme la fin de la crise égyptienne est an appoint appréciable acquis à l'exercice en cours.

En diminuant notre activité da côté de nos reports et avances sur titres, votre Conseil avait le devoir de développer les autres bran ches de son programme. Comme nous le dision plus haut, la crise n'a pas atteint les forces vives du pays. Sa richesse agricole, les transactions 80881 importantes que rémunératice anxquelles elle donne lieu, constituent toujours un vaste champ d'activité. Votre Conseil a donc tenu à diriger toute son attention de ce côté, d'autant plus que les affaires de cette nature, faites sur des bases sérieuses, constituent des avances d'un caractère temporaire et jouissant d'une garantie, de premier ordre Nous avons donc le plaisir de vons Annoncer que notre service Marchandises, déja organise, fonctionne régulièrement et promet, pour une année de début, des résultats satisfaisants.

Nous avons acquis, an debut de cette année, pour y établir le siège de votre Société, l'immeuble ex-Compagnie du Gaz, Rue Chérif Pacha. Cet immeuble, plas adapté aux besoins de nos divers services de Banque, nous per: mettra de leur donner un plus grand dévelop. pement.
Au cours de cet exercice nous avons éts heureux de nous assurer le précieux concours de Monsieur C. de Tschudi en qualité d'Admi. nistrateur de votre société, nomination que vous avez à ratifier.
Vous avez aussi à procéder à la nomination de deax Censenrs pour l'exercice 1907-1908, et å fixer leur allocation, MM. Paul Fabri et Marc Calamaro étant arrivés au terme de leur mandat.
Mr. Campos then remarked that out of the LE. 178,286 representing the advances not guaranteed, the Board had obtained from the 31st July Inst the guarantee for a total of LE 45,000.
A shareholder asked for some enlightenment and demanded whether these advances did not possess any guarantee.

Mr. Campos : No, but among the debtors there are some perfectly solvable persons of repute. In order to meet any mischance the Board had deducted L E. 75,000 from the profits. This, together with L.E. 7,500 from the profits of the preceding year, gave a total of L E. 82.500, which figures under the head of "Ponda de Prévoyance."
Mr Hazzan: Why are the holders of the founders shares to receive nothing?
Mr. Campos : The sum carried forward was for the account of the founders shares.
Mr. Hazzan persisted and he was supported by almost all the shareholders present in asking for a dividend for the founders shares.
The Board after some deliberation decided to give a dividend. The total to be thus distributed is about L.E. 2,000.

Mr. Fabri was re-elected auditor with Messrs. Russell, Kerr, and Wyatt, in place of Mr. Calamaro, who retired. Mr Von Tschudi was proposed by the Board as a director and the appointment was unanimously approved by the shareholders.
In consequence of the decision taken a dividend of P.T. 11. mills. 7 will be distributed to the shareholders of the third issue and the founders conpon on the 4th inst.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Jeudi 31 Octobre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 5 3/4 pour cent.

An Stock Exchange, le Consolidé a baissé hier de 1/8 à 82 1/8. L'Unisée est restée inchangée à 102 1/2. La National Bank a baisse de 3/8 å 20 7/8 et in Daira également de 3/8 i 13. La Delta Light et l'Agricole ont été soutenues à 10 1/8 et 7 1/8, respectivement.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 3 francs à 686. La Banque d'Athènes a été ferme à 110. Les Lots Torcs ont rétrograde A 166 en perto de 2 francs.

Ici, comme on pouvait s'y attendre vu la faiblesse du groupe égyptien en Europe, le marché n'a pas fait montre de meilleures dispositions et m nouveau recul s'est produit sur presque toutes les valeurs, malgré le pen d'af. faires traitéca.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Netional Bank recule à 20 5/8 et l'Agricole à 7 15/16. La Banque d'Athènes est également atteinte à 106 et la Banqne d'Orient à 115. Le Comptoir Financier se tasse à 2 3/4 et sa part à 1 3/4.

La Delta Light fléchit à 9 7/8 et la Rainleh Railways à 4.3/8. L'action capital Eaux du Caire revient à 110 et les Jouissances à 182. La Daïra Sanieh baisse à 12 13/16. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est plus faible à 682 683 ainsi que son obligation ancienne å 296 et la nouvelle À 253. La Bebéra est ramenée d'on seul coup à 22. L'Allotment tombe à 115/16. L'Union Foncière s'alourdit à 4 11/16. Les parts de fondateur Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été très actives à P.T. 34-35. La Brasserie des Pyramides est en baisse à 75 et les Frigorifiques à 2 1/8-1/4.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovicb se raffermissent a 16 3/4 tandis que les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) tombent a 5. Les Ritz sont réalisés à 07/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la New Egyptian s'allaisse à 10/8. Les Batatea semblent rouloir se relever à 07/16 alors que leur fondateur perd 8/4 « 1 7/8. La Satt and Soda recale encore a 16/6 et les Spinning a 0 1/4-6/16. Las Hooker ne résistent pas mieux à 01 4-5/16 comme l'United Land qui retombe à 01/4.
Le Marché des Valeurs étant fermé demain Vendredi 1er Novembre à l'occasion de la Fête de la Toussaint, le prochain numéro de notre circolaire ne paraltra que le landi 4 No. vembre.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres les passages suivants :

"Les dépêches ont du vous apprendre par le menu les incidents financiers de New York et la debacle de quelques poissantes sociétés financières. Tous ces "Krachs" doivent être attribués à la chûte da cuivre et à la guerre acharnée que se font certains magnata américains.

"Notre marché a assez bien résisté à la bourrasque, notamment nos Consolidés qui ont fait bonne figure. Les valeurs de chemin de fer paraissent vouloir aussi se relever depois que la crainte d'une grève générale a disparu pour le moment.

Néanmoins, la tendance générale da marché a été durant toute la semaine faible et indécise, et très influencée par les événements de New York. A vrai dire, le marché monétaire a beaucoup plus souffert et l'on s'attend à une élévation très prochaine du taux d'escompte de la Banque d'Angleterre, à la suite de la haosse continue de l'escompte hors banque et des besoins de l'Amérique.

Le marché des valeurs égyptiennes a été en général calme avec tendance plutôt faible. Les Affaires sont assez restreintes et l'Egypte continue d'envoyer des ordres de vente. Les Khe. divial Mail ont fait exception à la règle générale, avançant de 21/6 À 22/6 sur des ordres d'achat ponr compte de l'Egypte."
Notre correspondant de Londres nous commonique les renseignements ci-après :

"Les "Egyptian Estates" se proposent d'é mettre ici £. 400,00 en Obligations première hypothèque 5%, dont £. 210,000 seraient à échanger contre une égale quantité d'obligations déjà cotées sur notre Bourse et £.190,000 seraient offertes en premier lieu aux détenteurs des £. 2.0,000 avec option de les convertir pendant cinq ans en actions ordinaires au
pair.

"Les Lat. 190.000 restantes seraient émises à 95 avec un "Underwriting Commission" de 2 1/2 % la Compagnie donnerait en garantie des terrains agricoles d'one valeur netto de lat. 450,000 ainsi qu'une somme de 1st.220,000 qui doit lui rentrer pendant les 4 années prochaines en règlement les terrains déjà ven
Carnet de l'actionnaire MM. les actionnaires de la "Banque d'Athènes" sont convoqués en Assemblée générale extraordinaire le 12/25 Novembre 1907 & 3 heures p m. au Siège Central à Athènes.
A l'ordre du jour : Modifications à apporter aux articles 21, 24, 26, 27, 28, 37 et 46 des Statuts.
Aux termes de l'art. 35 des Statuts, ont seals droit de prendre part à l'assemblée les actionnaires possédant au moins cinquante actions.

- MM. les actionnaires de la "Société Générale de Pressage et de Dépôts" sont informés que l'Assemblée générale ordinaire du 28 Oc tobre 1907 a fixé les intérêts et lo dividende pour l'exercice 1906-1907 à 10% soit lat. 2. 1 sh. par action.

Un acompte de Let. 0.12 xb, ayant été payé en Mars dernier, le solde soit lat. 1.8 sh. par action, est payable à partir du 5 Novembre prochain Ala Banque Impériale Ottomane A Alexandrie contre remise du coupon numéro 18.

The crew of the destroyer "Skory" has mutinied and bombarded the town. A gunboat and three destroyers and the batteries returned the fire. The ringleaders have been killed. The "Skory" was riddled with shells and driven ashore to prevent her sinking. The survivors have been arrested.
(Reuter)

The loyal destroyers approached the "Skory" from three sides and bombarded her heavily. Her boilers exploded. There were only three survivors. A plan of simultaneous mutiny on "shore failed, from two to three score of the mutineers being shot by the loyal chasseurs.
(Reuter)
The torpedo-destroyer "Skory" has sunk.
(Havas)

(Havas)

div.head: THE ADDRESS TO WINSTON CHURCHILL
div.p: Nicosia, October 24.

The addresses of, and replies to deputations of the Elected members of the Legislative Council, both Moslem and Greek, received by Mr. Winston Churchill, when at Nicosia, have been published for general information.

The Moslem address contained the follow. ing striking, passages : "The non-attendance of the Moslen community at the ceremony of meeting and welcoming you, Sir, was due to the fact of their having been unable to reconcile with their national feelings their appearance among Greek flags. We absolutely repudiate the union of the Island with Greece, and request that the delivering of speeches on the subject in places of official and high standing may be categorically prohibited." The indulgence hitherto shown in such matters having increased the boldness of the Greeke, we are even at this moment hardly able to pass through the streets because of the shouts of "zeto" and the display of Greek flags." "Neither do we want autonomy. We particularly desire that the conduct of public affairs should in any case be presided over by im. partial and just Englisbmen. The granting of more extensive powers to the Legislative Council being also dangerous for the future, the preservation of the status quo is under all circumstances to be preferred." "......the tranquillity of the country being threatened by reason of this true state of things, it is extremely necessary that British troops in sufficient numbers should be stationed in all parts of the Island as a means of inspiring the public with a feeling of security."

The Greek address was presented by the Bishop of Kitium. This, after a somewhat discursive and historical retrospect, and a declaration on the "national Aspirations" and "political rights" of that portion of the community, contained the following bold suggestions : I. That the Legislative Council should in future consist exclusively of elected members in proportion to the population of the two predominant races of the Island, the Government being represented by the members of the Executive Council (three in number without voting power.
2. That the Legislative Council should be Accorded full liberty in the management of the general interests of the Island--the power of disallowance being reserved to the Crown.
3. That a larger share in the Executive Administrative and Judicial work of the Government should be entrusted to natives.

A long statement upon the financial conditions of Cyprus then followed, in which the hardships of the Turkish Tribute were duly reviewed and enlarged upon in a glow of language and wealth of words which, to an unprejudiced reader, seem to resemble the cheap and flashy setting which detracts from rather than sets off the beauties of a genuine stone.

Mr. Churchill, in an effective reply, expressed his inability to discern at present any way by which the influence and power of the Greek elected members could be increased which would not, in fact, involve a surrender of sovereignty and an inability, not only on the part of the British Government but also on that of the Moslem minority, to exercise any further influence on the course of affairs. Referring to the question of union with Greece Mr. Churchill spoke very clearly. "In these circumstances," he said, "and in view of the considerations which I have put before you, it is the duty of Great Britain to remain in occupation of Cyprus, and I think it is my duty to say to you that his Majesty's Government cannot recognize that the time has come when the Island should be abandoned, or when any change in its political status should be effected." With reference to the tribute and the present experimental arrangement for 3 years for a grant-in-aid from the Home Government of £50,000 a year, Mr Churchill said "It is quite true that the new arrangement of the grant-in-aid is limited to a period of three years. But I daresay that when the time to reconsider it is reached, if the British Govern men see encouraging results from the new arrangement already achieved, it will certainly not be altered to the disadvantage of the Island."

div.head: High Commissioner's Report.
div.p: The High Commissioner's annual report for 1906-7, just issued, contains some interesting reading.

The revenge for the year ander review, apart from the grant-in-aid was £286,878, the largest over recorded in the history of Cyprus. The expenditure, exclusive of the tribute, was £182,066, or £36,000 above the average of the 5 preceding years. The value of imports, exclusive of specie, was £501,921 and the value of exports £464,392. "The figures," we read, "for imports are the highest on record, and those for exports have been exceeded only on three occasions since the British occupation. They all point to the maintenance of the general prosperity of the last three years, and the increased imports of many articles of diet, cotton piece goods, silk and woollen manufacturers, haberdashery and millinery, furniture and arms, all speak of the improved well-being and comfort of the people."

In regard to crime it is satisfactory to learn that the increase of crime is not of a serious nature, and that, on the whole, there has been & decrease in the number of cases before the Superior Courts." Under the heading of Post and Telegraphs it is stated that the local postage of letters, postcards, newspapers, books, samples, and circulars showed, during the year, an increase of 80,718 over the number of the previous year, while local parcels showed an increase of 298.

Our Anglo-Bgyptian friends, who have ventured across to this Island on business or in search of holiday rest, will read with curious interest that "The foreign mail service was greatly assisted by the conclusion of a contract with the Limassol Steam. ship Company, which, for a subsidy of £4,750 is bound for three years to maintain & regular weekly service with Egypt. The pune. tuality of this service and the fairly good Accomodation provided on the company's steamers are giving satisfaction to the general public and are assisting the passenger and goods trade of the Island. Sacb grounds for complaint as exist are due to the inexperience of the company, and will doubtless be removed when the management gains more practical knowledge of the tastes and requirements of the public."

The High Commissioner's observations on the climate of Cyprus will, also appeal to your readers. "The hotel and camp accomodation to be found on Mount Troodos are becoming known to, and are being taken advantage of by, a certain number of English and other residents in Egypt, who enjoy and benefit by the pure dry, bracing air of the Cyprus pine forests, and the perfect climate and the beautiful scenery come as a revelation to the exhausted visitors from Cairo, Alexandria, or Port Said."

div.head: Cotton-growing.
div.p: Sir Alfred Jones (president of the British Cotton-Growing Association) has received the following letter from Mr. Churchill, M.P. :-
H.M.S. Venus, Port Said, October 14, 1907.

My dear Sir Alfred Jones.-Cyprus seems to offer very considerable cotton possibilities, and I think the British Cotton-Growing Association should not overlook this field of enterprise. I enclose you a memo, which I have had prepared by the Director of Agriculture in Cyprus, and which should, I think, be published in our Lancashire papers.
Yours sincerely, WINSTON S. CHURCHILL.

Cyprus produces "dry" and "wet" cotton, ie, non-irrigated and irrigated. The former is poor in quality and little renumerative, and is mostly used for local consumption. The latter kind is that chiefly exported. It ranks second on the Marseilles market, being placed next after the Egyptian variety "Jumel."

The following are the exports of raw cotton during the last six years :--1901, 307,552lb. ; 1902, 303,968lt. ; 1903, 236,2081b. ; 1904, 168.8961b ; 1905, 472,9761b.; 1906, 452,928lb., As against 6 million lb. exported in Venetian times, although locusts, now practically ex. terminated, then abounded Production in those days was, therefore, many times greater than now. The chief reasons for this decline in production are:-
1. Want of capital among small farmers.
2. The need of more extended irrigation facilities.
3. The want of direct steamship communication with England.
4. The relative high rates of freight to Eng. land compared with those from other producing countries.

5. The deterioration of seed, which needs continually renewing. ('The Agricultural Department has imported fresh seed tor the last two years which has been sown at Athlassa Chiftlik; the produce having been distributed among farmers,)
6. Owing to the large production elsewhere and at low prices.
In 1893 American seed was imported and sown with good results, but in four years it had reverted to the native type.

Experiments have been conducted by the Agricultural Department this year in different parts of the island with five varieties of Ame. rican and Sea Island cotton seed. Excellent results were obtained in each case from Allen's long staple and Sea Island, which indicates that these two varieties could be profitably grown. These experiments are being continued this year, since, in the case of cotton as in all other experimental work, a period must be allowed for tentative and preliminary trials.

Both Professor Dunstan and the British-Cotton Growing Association have urged that careful experiments be made by the Agricultural Department with different varieties of seed as a preliminary to more extended operations. The association considered that £1,000 per annum should cover the cost of such experiments ; they, on their prrt, co-operating by (1) providing the seed; (2) looking after the disposal of the crop; and (3) making annually a grant of £100.
To this proposition the Colonial Office replied (June 1, 1905) that they were not prepared to sanction additional expenditure beyond slightly strengthening and improving
the organization of the Agricultural Department for this purpose.

The High Commissioner in his despatch No. 33 of January 27, 1905, states :-I am entirely in accord with Professor Dunstan in his wiew that the decadent ootton industry of Cyprus could be re-established and made the foundation of the future prosperity of the island. The efforts of a competent and practical Agricultural Department, together with an augmentation of the existing water supply, would undoubtedly do much for the extension of improved cotton cultivation, but the results so obtained will be of ao benefit to the English market until the provision of means for ocean transport and the reduction of freight rates and other charges render that market more attractive than those at Marseilles and Trieste.

As regards the actual position of cotton-growing in Cyprus (putting asido "dry cotton," which, as already said, is not remunerative). the "wet" cotton is on an average as good in quality and as remunerative as that of Egypt. Its profitable cultivation could be further Assured if, over and above the considerations of capital, irrigation, and transport facilities, the cultivator could be brought (1) to improve the quality of his produce by the distribution to him of selected native seed or of imported seed, so as to obtain kinds specially suited to the different localities the native seed is at present a degenerate form of Orleans seed crossed during the course of time with the old original seed of the country); (2) to learn by actual experience that for a superior quality of cotton he will obtain a relatively higher price ; and (3) by the introduction of fertilizers and improved implements of husbandry.
Large acres of land are suitable for cotton-growing if irrigation were possible.

div.head: Prices of Corn
div.p: Prices of corn have maintained the very high level last reported, and considerable exports to Egypt and elsewhere are in progress. Enhanced prices must be expected so long as there is the present shortage of labour Owing to this shortage and the independent spirit of the Cypriot working man when he has a little money in his pocket the rate of wages in nearly all branches of work' continues to rise, Ordinary unskilled labour is scarcely obtainable at 15 piastras (1/8d) per day, while masons and skilled workmen are receiving 5/per day. The expediency of importing labour is now being seriously considered, and, we believe a trial has already been made in some instances.

div.head: The Rainy season.
div.p: The weather has now broken, summer is gone, and the rains have descended. At Limassol last Saturday many streets were running streams and were impassable in parts, except on mens' backs. Here we have had some heavy rains and at Nicosia the river Pedias has been down in flood. A sharp fall in the temperature immediately followed the rains, but warm weather cannot be said to have entirely left us. Cotton picking has been summarily put a stop to, though little of value remained to be gathered. Young trees, dependent on the rainfall, will have a chance of recovering after the long summer drought, while everywhere the plough will now be busy.

div.head: Summer Weather.
div.p: The observations made on Mount Troodos during the summer months showed an absolute mean temperature of 64 25, the mean maximum having been 75 4 and the mean minimum 53.1.

div.head: Personalla.
div.p: Mr. T. Hatton Richards, Assistant Secretary to Government, and Mrs. Hatton Richards returned to Cyprus last mail from England. Mr. F. LI. Edwards, the newly appointed British chaplain at Nicosia, also arrived by the same boat.
Dr. Heidenstam, chief medical officer, was taken ill suddenly last week and, though slowly recovering, is still confined to his room.

div.head: TURKS AND GREEKS.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,----It is amusing to see in the letter you publish from a "former resident of Cyprus" in your issue of yesterday how incongruous and self contradictory arguments people use who wish to grasp the first come opportunity to give vent to their anti-Hellenic feelings.

I will not deal with the merits of the Cypriots' claims for anion with Greece, which must at present remain a purely academic question. Yet how can your humanitarian correspondent, who is raising his voice for the safety of the 50,000 Turks of Cyprus, conciliate his claim for the British protection of these people with the statements in the letters of Mr. Halid's Cretan correspondents, on whose authority his arguments are based, and in which it is declared that "these outrages (of Cretan Greeks against Turks) occur more frequently in the British zone than elsewhere" ? If, as bis letter implies, your correspondents only care is for the safety of the Torks of Cyprus, why does be not urge on the strength of the above statement for a more adequate and complete protection of his favourites by, let us say, the Russians ? For if Greeks of Cyprus are the same as the Greeks of Crete and the British in the first island analogous to those in the
second how are the poor Turks guaranteed from the same "outrages" (sic) as are occurring against them in Crete ?

So much for your correspondents arguments, As regards Mr. Halid's statements, he is the first to inform us about any savageries occur. ring in Crete against the Islamic population in the island, where lately an office in the cabinet was given to a Tork in a country purely Hellenic. To have a proof of the perfect harmony that exists between the Turks and Greeks it is sufficient to observe the position of the Musulman deputies in the actual Cretan parliament, where far from 'forming a solid group, as would be the case if they had a special and common grievance, they are ranged part of them with the government and others with the opposition. To a man of even a small thinking capacity this is sufficient to refute all the statements made by Mr. Halid's correspondents "Cretan dignitaires" nothing more or less than vile calumniators.

It is ridiculous of Mr. Halid, who holds the respectable post of a professor in Cambridge, to preach to Greeks about humanity and justice while so little respect is shown by his race to the lives, property and honour of their compatriotes in Macedonia, and bell is let loose against the Greeks of Epirus in the person of Governor Theifoullah Pasha. One can only wonder that reprisals are not taken in Thessaly, Cyprus and Crete, where Turks live happier and more content than they do in Turkey.
I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant
BASIL J. CANARI.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET:
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
LIVERPOOL, October 24.
There has been a slightly improved enquiry for spot Egyptians this week, but it is freely met. Quotations of Brown are raised its plb. and Uppers 1/16.
In Futures a fair business has been done and the following are the latest quotations -
Oct. 9.62 Jan. 9.51 Apr. 9.51 July 9.53
Dec. 9.64 Mar. 9.51 June 9.52

American Futures. There has been a week of nervous excitement in consequence of the unsettled condition of Financial affairs in America. A semi-panicky feeling seemed to prevail during the early part of the week in America and meetings were held by many Banks, and large financial houses, with the object of devising means to avoid further depression of securities. One large Financial house closed its doors, and being followed by some smaller ones the effect on our Market was consequently very depressing. The one redeeming point of the situation is the healthy state of the Spinning trade all over the world. For the moment speculation is killed, and we can see little hope of revival of speculative interest until the financial atmosphere on the other side is more clear.
The latest values are, delivery :-

div.head: CRAB WITH 2,000,000 JOINTS.
div.p: The crab known as the scale-tailed apus was believed to have become extinct in Great Britain fifty years ago, the last recorded specimens being taken in the ponds on Hampstead Heath. But now it has turned up again in some numbers in two ponds on Preston Merse, near Southwick, in Kirkcudbrightshire. Abont 2 inches long, the apns bears a very striking likeness to that remarkable creature the King Crab, and this (writes a correspondent in the "Daily Graphic") because the fore part of the body is covered by a great semi-circular shield or carapace, while, as in the King Crab, it swims on its back. In the great number of its legs the scale-tailed apus has few rivals, while in the number of the joints which these share between them no other creature can compare. The naturalist Schäffer once essayed the task of counting them, and made the magnificent total of 1,802,604. Latreille went one better, and put down the number at a round 2,000,000.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra).
